Organisms that live on the ocean floor.
The gravitational pull of this causes tides.
The area that extends from the low-tide line to the edge of the continental shelf.
One form of nektonic live.
One element that is abundant in the ocean.
Destructive waves that are usually caused by earthquakes or landslides.
One factor that affects ocean life.
Region that extends to an average depth of 6000 meters.
One form of benthic life.
The zone of the sea that extends to a depth of about 2000 meters.
The highest point of a wave.
The lowest point of a wave.
Animals and plants that float at or near the surface of the ocean.
An object in space that produces its own heat and light.
Of or related to the Moon.
A huge piece of Earth's crust that moves very slowly.
A large flat area of land at the mouth of a river.
A streak of light made by a burning meteoroid in Earth's atmosphere.
The measure of the amount of matter an object contains.
A natural structure on Earth's surface.
The name for magma that reaches the Earth's surface.
The hole left when a volcano collapses.
A bowl-shaped area that may form at the top of a volcano around the central vent.
An opening where molten rock and gas leave a volcano.
Magma that forces itself across rock layers hardens into this landform.
A molten mixture of rock-forming substances, gases, and water from the mantle.
Magma that squeezes between horizontal rock layers hardens to form this land feature.
Evidence of past life preserved in rock.
An explanation that ties together many hypothesis and observations.
The largest division of geologic time.
A subdivision of the eras in geologic time.
The most specific classification of living things.
A random change to a gene that results in a new trait.
A unit of geologic time that includes two or more periods.
Always pulls things from high places to low places.
A huge sheet of moving ice.
A jumble of many sizes of sediment.
A teardrop-shaped pile of jumbled sediment.
The breaking down of rock material and carrying it away.
Curves that develop in an old river.
Winds may top 250 mph.
A pattern of weather.
When there is too much water for the ground to absorb.
Wearing away of rock; caused by wind.
A wave carries this.
A water mass moving in one direction.
A rhythmic movement that carries energy through matter or space.
A mountain on the ocean floor that is completely underwater.
The measure of the amount of salts dissolved in seawater.
